misconceptions.name: Implemented an unrelated acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description:
The submitted program solves a different problem (computing average acceleration from v0, v1, and t) instead of the assigned task (reading 5 integers and printing the sum of the even ones). As a result, none of the rubric requirements are met.

Rubric-based evaluation:
- Reading 5 integers from input (0/1): The program reads 3 double values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers, and the input prompt does not match the required behavior.
- Loop structure to process inputs (0/1): There is no loop; the program does not iterate over 5 inputs.
- Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0) (0/1): There is no conditional logic related to even/odd numbers.
- Accumulating sum and printing result (0/1): The program computes acceleration and prints it instead of accumulating and printing the sum of even numbers.

Feedback per category:
- Reading 5 integers from input: Your code reads three decimal values for velocities and time, not five integers. For this question, you needed to prompt for and read exactly 5 integers (e.g., using nextInt in a loop).
- Loop structure to process inputs: The program uses no loop, so it cannot process 5 separate inputs in a scalable way. You should use a for-loop that runs 5 times to read and process each integer.
- Conditional check for even numbers: There is no check for even numbers. You needed an if-statement using n % 2 == 0 to decide whether to include each number in the sum.
- Accumulating sum and printing result: Instead of computing (v1 - v0) / t, you should maintain an integer sum variable that starts at 0 and add each even number to it, then print "Sum of even numbers: " followed by the sum.

Overall feedback: This submission appears to be for a different question (average acceleration) and does not address the required task of summing even numbers from 5 integers. Re-read the problem statement carefully and ensure that your input variables, control structures (loop and if), and output message all match the specified behavior.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can submit a program that calculates average acceleration using v0, v1, and t for this question, and that will satisfy the requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must specifically read 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each one with n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers, and then print that sum. Any other problem (such as calculating acceleration) does not meet the requirements.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Computes acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing selected inputs
No loop over 5 inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
Output message reports average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code from a different assignment (average acceleration) or did not carefully read/align their solution with the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Compare your code line by line against the problem statement. First, design the algorithm for THIS task: (1) initialize sum = 0; (2) loop 5 times: read an integer, if it is even (n % 2 == 0) then add it to sum; (3) after the loop, print the sum. Then write code that directly implements this algorithm, and avoid reusing code that was written for different problems such as acceleration.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to code structure (inputs, loop, conditionals, output)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the submission (variable names, prompt text, arithmetic formula, and output message) corresponds to an average-acceleration problem, with no elements related to summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: Code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation using v0, v1, and t, with no handling of 5 integers, no loop, no even-number check, and no sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Task Misalignment (Solved wrong problem)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to calculate average acceleration based on three double inputs (v0, v1, t), which is entirely unrelated to the requested task of reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of the even ones. This indicates a critical misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believed the assignment required calculating acceleration, possibly confusing it with a different exercise or prompt.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requested task was to calculate the sum of even numbers from 5 user-provided integers, requiring a loop structure, conditional checking (modulo operator), and initialization of an accumulator variable.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Code calculates a derivative (acceleration) instead of a sum (accumulation)
Title of the class and output messages reference acceleration
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to align the implemented solution with the stated assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always double-check that your code addresses every core requirement specified in the prompt. Ensure the number of inputs, data types, and final calculation match the task description.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as the student's code, file name, and output messages explicitly address a different problem (acceleration calculation) completely unrelated to the 'Sum of Even Numbers' prompt.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to solving a physics problem (acceleration) instead of the assigned math problem (sum of even numbers).

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Input
misconceptions.description: The student used `input.nextDouble()` for floating-point values (doubles) when the problem required reading 5 integer values.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either didn't notice the required data type or defaulted to using 'double' for numerical input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The variables should be declared as `int` and input read using `input.nextInt()` to accurately handle integer values, as specified by the task (Sum of Even Numbers).
symptoms: Use of `double` variable declarations
Use of `nextDouble()` method
misconceptions.root_cause: Misclassification of variable types necessary to fulfill the prompt, likely overshadowed by the general task misalignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Pay close attention to specified data types in the prompt (e.g., 'integer' vs. 'decimal' or 'double'). Use `nextInt()` for integers and `nextDouble()` for floating-point numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the code explicitly uses `double v0 = input.nextDouble();` three times instead of reading integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Iterative Structure
misconceptions.description: The student failed to implement a loop (e.g., `for` or `while`) necessary to process five separate input numbers efficiently and repeatedly apply the summing logic.
misconceptions.student_belief: Inputs could be processed sequentially without needing a structured loop, or the student did not recognize the need for repetition 5 times.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To handle a fixed number of repeated actions (like reading, checking, and summing 5 numbers), a `for` loop is the appropriate and expected structure.
symptoms: Absence of `for` or `while` keywords
Repetitive sequential input calls
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding of when to apply iterative control flow.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: When a task requires performing the same action multiple times (e.g., handling 5 inputs), use a loop structure to manage the repetition.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No loop structure is present in the code, which is essential for handling 5 inputs efficiently and adhering to the prompt's implied structure.

evidence.note: The logic is sequential and does not contain any loop structure to handle multiple inputs in a generalized way, failing the requirement to process 5 inputs.

misconceptions.name: Complete misunderstanding of problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem (calculating acceleration from physics) instead of the assigned problem (summing even numbers from 5 integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program to calculate average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only the even-numbered values among them.
symptoms: Program prompts for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Uses floating-point arithmetic instead of integer operations
Calculates acceleration formula instead of filtering and summing even numbers
Output shows 'average acceleration' instead of 'sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not carefully read or understand the problem statement. They may have solved a different assignment or copied code from a different problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task requires: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Check each with n % 2 == 0 to identify even numbers, (3) Sum only the even numbers, (4) Print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) with no overlap in logic, variables, or output format with the assigned task. The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Program reads 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers as required
Calculates physics acceleration formula instead of summing even numbers
Output is 'average acceleration' not 'sum of even numbers' as specified in requirements

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of a program that reads 5 integers and prints the sum of the even ones. This indicates a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and outputs the average acceleration ( (v1 - v0) / t ).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, examine each one, and compute the sum of only the even numbers using a loop and an if-condition (n % 2 == 0). It should then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Uses three double variables (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers.
No loop is present to process five separate inputs.
No conditional logic to test for even numbers.
Final output is 'The average acceleration is ...' rather than 'Sum of even numbers: ...'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this question and a different assignment (average acceleration), or re-using a previous solution without adapting it to the new problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement and list the required steps in plain language before coding. Then map each step to code: (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop 5 times, (3) in each iteration, check if the number is even using n % 2 == 0, and (4) add even numbers to a running sum and print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (input names, formula, output message) targets an acceleration problem and does not address reading 5 integers or summing even numbers, so it is highly likely the student misinterpreted the task.

evidence.note: This code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration, with no loop or even-number logic, showing the student implemented the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Fundamental Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) and failed to address the required task (calculating the sum of five even integers). This suggests a severe misunderstanding or misreading of the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they were supposed to write a program that calculates average acceleration, or they submitted code meant for a different question entirely, without adjusting it for the current requirement (summing even numbers).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires writing a program to read 5 integers and compute the sum of only those inputs that are even.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration, not sum of evens.
Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs.
File name and variable names (v0, v1, t, acceleration) are completely unrelated to the task.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading the prompt or submitting incorrect code intended for another problem set.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the prompt for Q1, which asks for the 'Sum of Even Numbers'. All four core components of the rubric (reading 5 inputs, looping, checking for evenness, and accumulating the sum) are missing from the current submission.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code is 100% irrelevant to the question asked. It addresses a kinematics problem (acceleration) instead of an arithmetic/looping problem (sum of even numbers).

evidence.note: The class name suggests the code addresses a completely different problem.
The entire logic calculates acceleration based on 3 doubles (v0, v1, t), failing to meet any requirement of reading 5 integers, looping, checking for evenness, or summing.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type for Input Reading
misconceptions.description: The student reads floating-point numbers (`double`) using `nextDouble()` instead of integer values (`int`) using `nextInt()`, which is required by the problem ('reads 5 integers').
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the input should be handled as real numbers (doubles).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem explicitly states to read 5 integers. The appropriate method for reading keyboard input as an integer in Java is `Scanner.nextInt()`.
symptoms: Use of nextDouble() when integers are required.
misconceptions.root_cause: Although likely a secondary error due to implementing the wrong problem, it shows a failure to select the correct data type/reading method based on the required input type (integer).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the `Scanner` method matches the expected data type. For integers, use `nextInt()`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The required input is '5 integers', but the implementation uses `nextDouble()`.

evidence.note: Input is read as `double`s using `nextDouble()`, not `int`s.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student has submitted a complete solution to a different problem (acceleration calculation) rather than the assigned sum-of-even-numbers problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they are solving an acceleration/physics calculation problem instead of reading and summing even integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires: read 5 integers, check each with (n % 2 == 0), accumulate even numbers into a sum, and print only that sum.
symptoms: Program asks for 'v0, v1, and t' (physics terms) not 'Enter 5 integers'
Calculates acceleration (v1-v0)/t instead of filtering evens
Reads only 3 inputs instead of 5
Class named 'AccelerationCalculator' instead of relating to even number sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either misread the assignment, confused this with a different exercise, or copy-pasted code from a previous problem without modification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment requirements carefully. You need: Scanner to read input → Loop (for i=0 to 4) → Check if each integer is even (n % 2 == 0) → Add to running sum → Print sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete certainty: the submitted code solves a physics acceleration problem, not the assigned sum-of-even-numbers problem. No overlap in logic, data types (doubles vs integers), or algorithm.

evidence.note: Entire program solves acceleration calculation, not sum of even integers. Physics formula is v1-v0)/t, not even number filtering.

misconceptions.name: Missing Loop for Multiple Inputs
misconceptions.description: Student does not use a loop structure to process the 5 required inputs. Instead, only 3 individual non-loop inputs are read.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading 3 individual inputs sequentially with separate `nextDouble()` calls is sufficient, rather than using a loop to handle 5 inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To efficiently process multiple inputs (5 integers), use a for-loop: `for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++)` to read each integer via `scanner.nextInt()` within the loop.
symptoms: No for-loop or while-loop present
Hard-coded only 3 input reads (v0, v1, t)
Cannot scale to handle the required 5 integers
Uses `nextDouble()` instead of `nextInt()`
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either does not understand loop structures or did not apply them to this input-reading task. They used a sequential procedural approach instead.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Wrap the input reading in a loop: `for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }`
related_concepts: Input parsing with scanners in loops
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute: the code shows no loop structure whatsoever. This is a fundamental absence, not a subtle misunderstanding.

evidence.note: Three sequential input reads without any loop. Should be inside a loop for 5 iterations.

misconceptions.name: No Even Number Filtering Logic
misconceptions.description: Student does not implement any conditional logic to check if numbers are even. The modulo operator (n % 2) is completely absent.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student does not appear to understand that even numbers must be filtered from odd ones using a conditional (n % 2 == 0) before adding to the sum.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A number is even if n % 2 == 0 (remainder is 0 when divided by 2). Only numbers passing this test should be added to the sum.
symptoms: No if-statement checking 'n % 2 == 0'
No modulo operator (%) used
All numbers would be added (if code were meant for this problem)
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either doesn't know the even-checking algorithm or didn't carefully read the problem requirements to implement selective summation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading each number, check: `if(num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; }` to add only even numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Complete certainty: no conditional logic for even-checking exists in the code.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: No conditional check for even numbers. Calculates acceleration instead of filtering evens.
